values.title: Provide synchronous control

content.raw:
Currently, the way to control the simulation is to publish ROS topics, which the simulation then reads and executes. Especially for our balance control it is important to have fast and synchronous control (~200Hz) of the robot. With synchronous control, we mean that the frequency of the control loop is guaranteed to be fixed with respect to the simulated world time.

If the simulation software or the control software runs faster or slower for whatever reason, the controller frequency changes in the simulated world.
content.html:
Currently, the way to control the simulation is to publish ROS topics, which the simulation then reads and executes. Especially for our balance control it is important to have fast and synchronous control (~200Hz) of the robot. With synchronous control, we mean that the frequency of the control loop is guaranteed to be fixed with respect to the simulated world time.

If the simulation software or the control software runs faster or slower for whatever reason, the controller frequency changes in the simulated world.

values.title: Audit environment variable settings in rosbuild integration

content.raw:
In our efforts to call out to rosbuild via `ExternalProject_Add()`, we added a bunch of environment variable setting.  Then we figured out that we were missing an override of `dh_auto_build` in the debian `rules` file.  We should go back and audit the environment variable settings, with the goal of reducing them to the minimum set.

The settings in questions happen in `ros/CMakeLists.txt` and are received in `ros/atlas_msgs/CMakeLists.txt`.
content.html:
In our efforts to call out to rosbuild via ExternalProject_Add(), we added a bunch of environment variable setting. Then we figured out that we were missing an override of dh_auto_build in the debian rules file. We should go back and audit the environment variable settings, with the goal of reducing them to the minimum set.

The settings in questions happen in ros/CMakeLists.txt and are received in ros/atlas_msgs/CMakeLists.txt.

values.title: polaris steering angle -> vehicle velocity bug

content.raw:
There seems to be a bug with the polaris ranger related to steering angle and the vehicle's velocity (or possibly it's a gazebo bug triggered by polaris). When you set the hand brake to 0, gas pedal to 1, and then gradually set the steering angle from 0 to 2 to 2.5 to 3 to 3.14 everything seems to be fine. But when you go from 0 directly to 3 the car completely stops every few meters. When using a lower gas the "step size" that it stops working at is even lower (e.g. for 0.5 gas it stops working with a 0 -> 2 transition already I think).

This problem does not seem to exist on the golf cart model (the golf cart however does not seem to be able to regulate the gas strength though). I thought it might be related to the friction coefficients the polaris model's wheels have which are missing on the golf cart but even after removing them the same problem persisted.

This bug also occurs when you have to stop the vehicle while driving at a "high" steering angle and then try to continue driving. You have to go back to 0 steering angle (or somewhere close to maybe, haven't verified whether it has to be exactly 0) in order to recover normal car behaviour.

Video demonstrating the bug (you can see the steering commands sent at the top): http://youtu.be/GLBSdJKZD0I

Same steering command (0 -> 3.14 transition) with golf cart: http://youtu.be/K2Y02CdGP0I

values.title: Error message about ROS plugin has wrong name of library

content.raw:
If you ran gazebo without loading the main ROS plugin, you get this error message:

     Error [gazebo_ros_camera_utils.cpp:234] Not loading plugin since ROS hasn't been properly initialized.  Try starting gazebo with ros plugin:
     gazebo -s libgazebo_ros_api.so

But the plugin is actually named `libgazebo_ros_api_plugin.so`.
content.html:

 Error [gazebo_ros_camera_utils.cpp:234] Not loading plugin since ROS hasn't been properly initialized.  Try starting gazebo with ros plugin:
 gazebo -s libgazebo_ros_api.so

But the plugin is actually named libgazebo_ros_api_plugin.so.

values.title: Provide realistic inertia and masses for the iRobot hands

content.raw:
For both hands the inertia is unrealistically large and the mass of the iRobot hands is about 7.5 kg a piece. 

For realistic control (angular control of the pelvis and position/force control of the fingers) it is necessary to have realistic values for inertia and mass. A large inertia makes position control of the fingers unrealistic (allows for very high gains) and a large mass affects the upper body orientation a lot when moving the hands.

values.title: Polaris Vehicle Interior Scale

content.raw:
Given that drcsim 2.0 is set to be released soon and the last polaris model update mainly added textures (very nice ones though! ;) ) and simplified collision models I figured I'll point out the existing scale issues with the current version before it's too late:

The outer dimensions seem to be correct (it's exactly 10cm too high according to the specs on the website but maybe polaris measured the real model with suspension system), but the distance between seat and steering wheel is way too small (only about 15cm, see [1] and [2]) and the seat might be too high as the robot can't even reach down to the pedals even when sitting at the edge of the seat (see [3]) even though it has the leg length of an average sized human.

When looking at [4] and [5] and the video in [6] you can see that for a normal person sitting in the ranger there is still plenty free space between their legs and the steering wheel and the pedals are easy to reach while sitting using just the lower leg + foot. Clearly this is currently not the case as you can see in [1], [2], and [3].

A fix to issue #103 should be included in 2.0 as well in order to be able to drive the model properly.

  -  [1] http://i.imgur.com/ZSBBpAC.png
  -  [2] http://i.imgur.com/2rzIaAJ.jpg
  -  [3] http://i.imgur.com/eKeiUYZ.jpg
  -  [4] http://www.quadtro.com/wp-content/gallery/polaris-ranger-ev/rangerev35.jpg
  -  [5] http://www.atv.com/gallery/gallery.php/d/39598-2/2011-Polaris-Ranger-EV-02.jpg
  -  [6] http://youtu.be/7AG5J_lQ8J8

values.title: polaris rotating while stationary

content.raw:
When placing atlas inside the vehicle using the fixed joint the vehicle rotates on its own: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gla81IgFJVo

This effect is present with both the extremely high friction parameters and the updated 1.0 friction (it's rotating even faster with the lower friction though I think).

After 250s simulation time using the 1.0 friction setting the vehicle is in this position: http://i.imgur.com/AKpg3ae.jpg

Update:
This effect appears with both the empty vehicle and with the atlas pinned to the vehicle, but the drift is a little sped up with atlas sitting inside I think (maybe due to increased disturbances). This also occurs with John's max_vel 100 fix for the wheels.

values.title: better treatment of ros::Time through /clock publication

content.raw:
Currently, simulation time is propagated by gazebo\_ros\_api\_plugin publishing `/clock` rostopic with update simulation time. 

pull request #77 tries to shortcut the ros time settings, but has some undesirable consequences (time going backwards).  Try to come up with a better strategy.

values.title: Proposal for pull requests with large merges

content.raw:
Bitbucket doesn't display large merges very well, especially when there are renamed files and directories. To make it easier to review pull requests with large merges, I would propose the following:

* Keep file renames/moves in separate commits from file modifications. Ideally include the `hg mv` commands in the commit message.

This probably won't help when merging branches, since all the commits will get lumped together, but it makes it easier to study the file modifications, when they're not mixed in with tons of adds and removes generated by `hg mv`.
content.html:
Bitbucket doesn't display large merges very well, especially when there are renamed files and directories. To make it easier to review pull requests with large merges, I would propose the following:

  • Keep file renames/moves in separate commits from file modifications. Ideally include the hg mv commands in the commit message.

This probably won't help when merging branches, since all the commits will get lumped together, but it makes it easier to study the file modifications, when they're not mixed in with tons of adds and removes generated by hg mv.

values.title: Use of math.h's abs() for doubles

content.html:
In the DRCVehiclePlugin (and maybe also in other code) you're using the c version of abs() to get the absolute value of doubles which causes them to get cut off. Either use <cmath> (which uses overloads of abs() for doubles) instead of <math.h> or fabs().

This causes wrong max velocity caps (FYI: your current velocity max is way too high, for the VRC/DRC in drive mode low it's 4.44 or 4.47 depending on whether you use kph or mph for conversion) and possibly also wrong tire angle ranges.

Two occurrences in DRCVehiclePlugin:

#!/osrf/drcsim/src/45a23d87af80af8bbc467a58382dba903f8572d7/plugins/DRCVehiclePlugin.cc?at=default#cl-207

#!/osrf/drcsim/src/45a23d87af80af8bbc467a58382dba903f8572d7/plugins/DRCVehiclePlugin.cc?at=default#cl-547

values.title: Split appropriate DRCSim ROS plugins out of atlas_msgs

content.raw: With drcsim's new file structure I can't really make any sense of where to find what. Why is everything crammed into ``ros/atlas_msgs`` and some things aren't? Why are things like ``gazebo_ros_laser`` or ``VRCPlugin`` in ``ros/atlas_msgs`` ... I would expect atlas messages to be in this folder and not all the gazebo related plugins. ``VRCPlugin`` is neither ROS related nor is it an atlas message, but yet you find it in ``ros/atlas_msgs``. Other plugins like ``DRCFirehosePlugin`` on the other hand are in ``drcsim/plugins/`` instead of ``ros/atlas_msgs``. Why do those 3 plugins get to be in their own cozy plugins folder while all the other 20 plugins need to share a crammed ``ros/atlas_msgs`` with 2 actual atlas messages hidden between all the gazebo plugins (two .. that's 10% of what's in there)? And why is ``JointCommands`` even so privileged to get its own repository? OSRF needs an equal opportunity commissioner for plugins and messages. ;)
content.html: With drcsim's new file structure I can't really make any sense of where to find what. Why is everything crammed into ros/atlas_msgs and some things aren't? Why are things like gazebo_ros_laser or VRCPlugin in ros/atlas_msgs ... I would expect atlas messages to be in this folder and not all the gazebo related plugins. VRCPlugin is neither ROS related nor is it an atlas message, but yet you find it in ros/atlas_msgs. Other plugins like DRCFirehosePlugin on the other hand are in drcsim/plugins/ instead of ros/atlas_msgs. Why do those 3 plugins get to be in their own cozy plugins folder while all the other 20 plugins need to share a crammed ros/atlas_msgs with 2 actual atlas messages hidden between all the gazebo plugins (two .. that's 10% of what's in there)? And why is JointCommands even so privileged to get its own repository? OSRF needs an equal opportunity commissioner for plugins and messages. ;)

values.title: /atlas/joint_states/effort[] should return force applied

content.raw:
currently, `AtlasPlugin::jointStates.effort` is set by calling `gazebo::Joint::GetForce`, which returns incorrect values (see [ticket](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/485/update-joint-getforce-to-return)).

We should change the joint state effort to be the _measured effort_ to be applied within the same time step.
content.html:
currently, AtlasPlugin::jointStates.effort is set by calling gazebo::Joint::GetForce, which returns incorrect values (see ticket).

We should change the joint state effort to be the measured effort to be applied within the same time step.

values.title: Slower camera framerate in drcsim 2.0

content.raw:
Using drcsim 1.3 I get a camera framerate of 24.178 on the rostopic and between 25 and 40 (????) in the Gazebo Image View for Atlas' MultiSense set to 30Hz with 1024x544 resolution.

Using drcsim 2.0 I get a camera framerate of 20.204 on the rostopic and an unknown number in the Gazebo viewer (doesn't show anything for the stereo camera) using the same camera resolution and framerate.

Conclusion: both are (far) below desired framerate and drcsim 2.0 with its synchronized camera only reaches 67% of the desired framerate. I looked into trying to run the threaded_sensors branch but couldn't get it to not segfault when loading Atlas (does it require a specific drcsim branch?).

values.title: Vehicle not deaccelerating

content.raw:
This bug is related to #103 and builds upon the current solution/workaround of either disabling brake torques for the front wheels or enabling gas torques for the front wheels:

When going off the gas pedal the vehicle keeps driving at constant speed without deaccelerating. When using the default model that has front brake torques enabled (and as a result can't be steered properly due to the bug in #103), the vehicle deaccelerates but that's due to the bug of brake torques being applied on all wheels at all times without actively braking.

values.title: Bad joint_states when in Nominal mode

content.raw:
Copied from [answers.gazebosim](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/1370/major-drc-control-issue-bad-joint_states-when-in/), posted by pbeeson:


We have found a bug where if we keep the Atlas robot pinned, that joint_states reported are correct. however, when switched to Nominal mode (the default when launching Atlas in an empty world after 10 seconds or so), that joint_states starts sending incorrect values BUT it seems like the internal joint controller sees the correct values, so any kind of closed loop control cannot be performed correctly.

To Reproduce:

Make a node that can sends a position to the neck joint through /atlas/joint_commands.

Launch atlas and watch /atlas/joint_states/positions[3] (the neck) start at 0, then after the robot becomes unpinned, it goes to -0.05 (or similar). Send the joint_command to ask the neck to return to 0. It doesn't (BECAUSE WE THINK IT BELIEVE INTERNALLY THAT IT IS ALREADY AT ZERO).

Now, send the service message to repin Atlas, and watch the joint value go back to 0.

While pinned, you can send the neck joint a new position goal, let's say 0.3. It will go there using the PID in the Gazebo plugin. Unpin the robot, and watch the value go to 0.25. So, because the joint_states for (AT LEAST) the neck joint are off by -0.05 radians, any closed loop control gets confused because it's always chasing this offset.
content.html:
Copied from answers.gazebosim, posted by pbeeson:

We have found a bug where if we keep the Atlas robot pinned, that joint_states reported are correct. however, when switched to Nominal mode (the default when launching Atlas in an empty world after 10 seconds or so), that joint_states starts sending incorrect values BUT it seems like the internal joint controller sees the correct values, so any kind of closed loop control cannot be performed correctly.

To Reproduce:

Make a node that can sends a position to the neck joint through /atlas/joint_commands.

Launch atlas and watch /atlas/joint_states/positions[3] (the neck) start at 0, then after the robot becomes unpinned, it goes to -0.05 (or similar). Send the joint_command to ask the neck to return to 0. It doesn't (BECAUSE WE THINK IT BELIEVE INTERNALLY THAT IT IS ALREADY AT ZERO).

Now, send the service message to repin Atlas, and watch the joint value go back to 0.

While pinned, you can send the neck joint a new position goal, let's say 0.3. It will go there using the PID in the Gazebo plugin. Unpin the robot, and watch the value go to 0.25. So, because the joint_states for (AT LEAST) the neck joint are off by -0.05 radians, any closed loop control gets confused because it's always chasing this offset.

values.title: Sim ignores velocity limits from URDF

content.raw:
[Link to original post on Gazebo Answers](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/1333/atlas-controller-ignores-limits-from-urdf/)

In the DRCSim 2.0, I have noticed that when sending position commands (to say for example the neck_ay joint), that the velocities reported by /atlas/joint_states are much higher than the velocity_limits defined in the URDF.

Furthermore, I've noticed that because there is no limit checking going on, if you are tuning the PID controller, and choose a bad value for a PID gain, you can easily cause Gazebo to crash with an Ogre error (presumably because the effort it commands is too high or low).
content.html:
Link to original post on Gazebo Answers

In the DRCSim 2.0, I have noticed that when sending position commands (to say for example the neck_ay joint), that the velocities reported by /atlas/joint_states are much higher than the velocity_limits defined in the URDF.

Furthermore, I've noticed that because there is no limit checking going on, if you are tuning the PID controller, and choose a bad value for a PID gain, you can easily cause Gazebo to crash with an Ogre error (presumably because the effort it commands is too high or low).

values.title: joint command message not interpreted properly

content.raw:
Currently in both the sandia and atlas plugins the joint ordering is hardcoded.

The joint command message has a 'name' array field. This ordering is not used by the plugins - so if joint angles aren't published in the ordering specified in the cpp of the plugins they aren't interpreted properly.

the plugins should be reading this order from the message and using a map.

This is a major bug and can be easily fixed.
content.html:
Currently in both the sandia and atlas plugins the joint ordering is hardcoded.

The joint command message has a 'name' array field. This ordering is not used by the plugins - so if joint angles aren't published in the ordering specified in the cpp of the plugins they aren't interpreted properly.

the plugins should be reading this order from the message and using a map.

This is a major bug and can be easily fixed.

values.title: Recent commit forces sim to start paused

content.raw: 10 days ago (Commit 3fd1279), Nate commited a change to run_gazebo in atlas_utils that forces Gazebo, when using the traditional launch files, to start the sim paused.  I know people have requested this behavior, but I think it's a bad default behavior for several reasons.  First, it requires the use of the gui, or at least a gazebo client, to unpause gazebo, which seems to be a weird thing to require from VRC teams using this for the DRC competition.  Second, while it is easy to add a '-u' argument in a launch file when the run-gazebo scipt is called, there is no equivalent for overriding the default '-u' in a launch file.  As of now, we are having to edit ALL of our launch files to call a local version of run-gazebo that doesn't start paused.  The alternative would be to write a plugin that unpauses when a ROS message is received, or to write a Gazebo client that simply unpauses then ends.  None of these are ideal, when the behavior could be to start unpaused, unless a '-u' flag is given in a launch file to pause.
content.html: 10 days ago (Commit 3fd1279), Nate commited a change to run_gazebo in atlas_utils that forces Gazebo, when using the traditional launch files, to start the sim paused. I know people have requested this behavior, but I think it's a bad default behavior for several reasons. First, it requires the use of the gui, or at least a gazebo client, to unpause gazebo, which seems to be a weird thing to require from VRC teams using this for the DRC competition. Second, while it is easy to add a '-u' argument in a launch file when the run-gazebo scipt is called, there is no equivalent for overriding the default '-u' in a launch file. As of now, we are having to edit ALL of our launch files to call a local version of run-gazebo that doesn't start paused. The alternative would be to write a plugin that unpauses when a ROS message is received, or to write a Gazebo client that simply unpauses then ends. None of these are ideal, when the behavior could be to start unpaused, unless a '-u' flag is given in a launch file to pause.

values.title: AtlasPlugin IMU Bug Fix

content.html:
The AtlasPlugin IMU was giving bad readings when the robot was spawned with a non-zero pitch, roll, and or yaw.

Found the bug. Bad transform multiplication.

Patch below:

diff -r c69ecab26a55 ros/atlas_msgs/AtlasPlugin.cpp
--- a/ros/atlas_msgs/AtlasPlugin.cpp    Wed Feb 27 11:19:18 2013 -0800
+++ b/ros/atlas_msgs/AtlasPlugin.cpp    Thu Feb 28 18:49:14 2013 -0600
@@ -624,7 +624,7 @@
       {
         // Get IMU rotation relative to Initial IMU Reference Pose
         math::Quaternion imuRot =
-          imuLinkPose.rot * this->imuReferencePose.rot.GetInverse();
+          this->imuReferencePose.rot.GetInverse() * imuLinkPose.rot;

         imuMsg.orientation.x = imuRot.x;
         imuMsg.orientation.y = imuRot.y;

values.title: Add environment variable to prevent `setup.sh` from sourcing ROS and Gazebo's `setup.sh`

content.raw:
I have my own custom setups for ROS and Gazebo, and would prefer to have the drcsim setup.sh file only add file to the package paths, but not re-source ROS and Gazebo's setup files (effectively resetting our setups). I would like to source drcsim's setup.sh after the fact, adding its changes, because I use a custom ROS workspace and Gazebo installation prefix for switching version more easily.

I've attached a patch as a suggested implementation, adding test cases for DRCSIM_SKIP_ROS_SETUP and DRCSIM_SKIP_GAZEBO_SETUP bash variables, which skips those setups if enabled. I also added DRCSIM_CUSTOM_SETUP, which enables both options.

This patch was created from the drcsim_2.1 branch.
content.html:
I have my own custom setups for ROS and Gazebo, and would prefer to have the drcsim setup.sh file only add file to the package paths, but not re-source ROS and Gazebo's setup files (effectively resetting our setups). I would like to source drcsim's setup.sh after the fact, adding its changes, because I use a custom ROS workspace and Gazebo installation prefix for switching version more easily.

I've attached a patch as a suggested implementation, adding test cases for DRCSIM_SKIP_ROS_SETUP and DRCSIM_SKIP_GAZEBO_SETUP bash variables, which skips those setups if enabled. I also added DRCSIM_CUSTOM_SETUP, which enables both options.

This patch was created from the drcsim_2.1 branch.

values.title: JointCommands position field set to 0.0 causes random jerks on 32bit builds

content.html:
Bug occurs when publishing on /atlas/joint_commands topic and not setting every position field to non-zero value (that means it happens when you set some joint positions to 0.0 or when you don't set them at all).

At first it behaves as expected, but after a few minutes of publishing on that topic in that way it causes some random and strong jerks in those not set joints accelerating the robot and eventually leading to its collapse (disappearing all its limbs but torso).

Reproducing the bug:

  1. Use code from this tutorial: http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/drcsim/2.0/sending_joint_controller_commands_over_ros

  2. Change the following lines in void SetJointStates():

 for (unsigned int i = 0; i < jointcommands.name.size(); i++)
      jointcommands.position[i] =
        3.2* sin((ros::Time::now() - startTime).toSec());

to:

 for (unsigned int i = 0; i < jointcommands.name.size(); i++)
      jointcommands.position[i] = 0.0;
 jointcommands.position[16] = 3.2* sin((ros::Time::now() - startTime).toSec());
  1. Build the node.
  2. Run simulator: roslaunch atlas_utils atlas.launch
  3. Disable gravity, delete the ground_plane
  4. Run the modified tutorial node: rosrun drcsim_joint_commands_tutorial publish_joint_commands
  5. Robot swings only one arm, it looks ok.
  6. Wait few minutes for a bug to occur. It varies from 2 minutes to over 10.

What else I've noticed:

The following also leads to bug:

// for (unsigned int i = 0; i < jointcommands.name.size(); i++)
//      jointcommands.position[i] = 0.0;
 jointcommands.position[16] = 3.2* sin((ros::Time::now() - startTime).toSec());

The following doesn't lead to bug:

 for (unsigned int i = 0; i < jointcommands.name.size(); i++)
      jointcommands.position[i] = 0.1;
 jointcommands.position[16] = 3.2* sin((ros::Time::now() - startTime).toSec());

I'm using 32bit Ubuntu 12.04 and drcsim-2.1, but it also happened on previous drcsim versions.

values.title: VRC Gates are Kryptonite for Visual Odometry

content.raw:
The tiny visual grids on the VRC gates are terrible for Visual Odometry. See attached images.

A 101 on Stereo Vision:

 descriptors are extracted (i.e. patterns of color gradient)

 100s descriptors are matched in left and right to give X, Y, Z points

 Inlier sets of XYZ points describe the stereoscopic information in the image.

 these features are aligned successively to give an estimate of motion.

These algorithms are based on the work of Andrew Howard, amoungst others.

However step 2 fails terribly for the images showing the VRC gates. The tiny checkerboard pattern is sensed identically without noise - despite being tiny features. (Real sensor noise would mean that the grid wouldn't be visable in reality). So the descriptors find 1000s of points - every grid point. Then matching between left and right is hugely complicated.

The result is that the feature depths are often estimated incorrectly - see the red loops. Hence motion estimation fails.

**Please remove the grids and just have plain red, green and blue color.** They gain nothing other than to cause unrealistic failures of algorithms that are tried and tested in the real world.

Additionally, why are the walls in the VRC tasks all blank? E.g. for manipulation? Can this be improved
content.html:
The tiny visual grids on the VRC gates are terrible for Visual Odometry. See attached images.

A 101 on Stereo Vision:

descriptors are extracted (i.e. patterns of color gradient)

100s descriptors are matched in left and right to give X, Y, Z points

Inlier sets of XYZ points describe the stereoscopic information in the image.

these features are aligned successively to give an estimate of motion.

These algorithms are based on the work of Andrew Howard, amoungst others.

However step 2 fails terribly for the images showing the VRC gates. The tiny checkerboard pattern is sensed identically without noise - despite being tiny features. (Real sensor noise would mean that the grid wouldn't be visable in reality). So the descriptors find 1000s of points - every grid point. Then matching between left and right is hugely complicated.

The result is that the feature depths are often estimated incorrectly - see the red loops. Hence motion estimation fails.

Please remove the grids and just have plain red, green and blue color. They gain nothing other than to cause unrealistic failures of algorithms that are tried and tested in the real world.

Additionally, why are the walls in the VRC tasks all blank? E.g. for manipulation? Can this be improved

values.title: Increase number of iterations in VRC worlds

content.raw:
In the VRC qualification worlds, the number of iterations for the ODE engine is set to 40. Increasing this number to 50 leads to large improvements for our walking controller, while not greatly impacting the simulation speed.

It seems that the default Gazebo settings for the physics engine have better performance than the settings in the VRC worlds, aka

```
#!xml

<ode>
        <solver>
          <type>quick</type>
          <dt>0.001</dt>
          <iters>50</iters>
          <sor>1.0</sor>
        </solver>
        <constraints>
          <cfm>0.0</cfm>
          <erp>0.2</erp>
          <contact_max_correcting_vel>100.0</contact_max_correcting_vel>
          <contact_surface_layer>0.0</contact_surface_layer>
        </constraints>
      </ode>



```
I propose that it gets changed to the gazebo defaults for now.
```
#!xml

<ode>
        <solver>
          <type>quick</type>
          <dt>0.001</dt>
          <iters>50</iters>
          <sor>1.3</sor>
        </solver>
        <constraints>
          <cfm>0.0</cfm>
          <erp>0.2</erp>
          <contact_max_correcting_vel>100.0</contact_max_correcting_vel>
          <contact_surface_layer>0.001</contact_surface_layer>
        </constraints>
      </ode>
```

I do think more testing is necessary  for the final parameters of the physics engine.
content.html:
In the VRC qualification worlds, the number of iterations for the ODE engine is set to 40. Increasing this number to 50 leads to large improvements for our walking controller, while not greatly impacting the simulation speed.

It seems that the default Gazebo settings for the physics engine have better performance than the settings in the VRC worlds, aka

<ode>
        <solver>
          <type>quick</type>
          <dt>0.001</dt>
          <iters>50</iters>
          <sor>1.0</sor>
        </solver>
        <constraints>
          <cfm>0.0</cfm>
          <erp>0.2</erp>
          <contact_max_correcting_vel>100.0</contact_max_correcting_vel>
          <contact_surface_layer>0.0</contact_surface_layer>
        </constraints>
      </ode>

I propose that it gets changed to the gazebo defaults for now.

<ode>
        <solver>
          <type>quick</type>
          <dt>0.001</dt>
          <iters>50</iters>
          <sor>1.3</sor>
        </solver>
        <constraints>
          <cfm>0.0</cfm>
          <erp>0.2</erp>
          <contact_max_correcting_vel>100.0</contact_max_correcting_vel>
          <contact_surface_layer>0.001</contact_surface_layer>
        </constraints>
      </ode>

I do think more testing is necessary for the final parameters of the physics engine.

values.title: Increase max range of all DRCSIM cameras to 300

content.raw:
Currently the camera simulation view volume is set to be smaller than the VRC environment, with the effect that as the robot moves around a small amount, mountains come into view, changing the skyline dramatically. This makes it hard for image-based visual registration algorithms, since the skyline is such a dominant feature.

See
http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/1896/drcsim-vrc-terrain-stripmine-those-mountains/
For other options (reduce size of VRC terrain, redesign terrain).

values.title: vrc rough terrain made up of steps

content.raw:
Most of the traversable parts of the current rough terrain used in the walking task consists of flat, horizontal areas connected via untraversable steep slopes. This essentially turns the problem of rough terrain walking into stair climbing or rock hopping instead of actual rough terrain walking with varying slope, etc. 

These steps seem to be a discretization effect resulting from specifying a heightmap scale of 46.9m along z, which causes the 256 possible heightmap values to be stretched along 46.9m resulting in ~18cm tall steps between each value in the heightmap.

It is unclear whether this is the way it's intended to be for the VRC or whether this will be changed towards a more realistic, "smoother" rough terrain that enables/requires actual rough terrain walking instead of just stepping with a flat foot. 

The terrain could be improved by either using a smaller scale along z and replacing the current tall mountains by billboards or buildings (e.g. 5-10m scale along z should be sufficiently high for this task while enabling a much higher resolution), or the other alternative would be to use a custom triangle mesh instead which allows more control about the terrain structure.

(I know you already know about this ... I think ... but I just wanted to write it down as a ticket as well. Additionally an official response whether it will stay this way for VRC or not would be appreciated ... I'll cross-post this on the drc forum).

values.title: Integral tie-back in AtlasPlugin.cpp seems wrong - causes control glitches

content.raw:
Per [thread](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/2309/integral-tie-back-in-atlasplugincpp-seems-wrong/),

The code at roughly [line 1066 in AtlasPlugin.cpp](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/084739a7530dd022180fee281b1d5ccffc6bbeb6/ros/atlas_msgs/AtlasPlugin.cpp?at=default#cl-1066) appears to be wrong. Specifically, it generally will invert the `kiq_i` term on a step change and saturate in the opposite of the commanded direction.

If a negative step is applied that results in a clamped force then the code can result in a `kiq_i` that is clamped at the positive limit. This results in a joint excursion in the opposite of the desired direction.

This is not a desired behavior. I would recommend simply removing the problematic code.

~~~
    // lock integral term to provide continuous control as system moves
    // out of staturation
    this->errorTerms[i].k_i_q_i = math::clamp(
            this->errorTerms[i].k_i_q_i + (forceClamped - forceUnclamped),
~~~

If a negative step is applied that results in a clamped force then the code can result in a kiq_i that is clamped at the positive limit. This results in a joint excursion in the opposite of the desired direction.

This is not a desired behavior. I would recommend simply removing the problematic code.

    // out of staturation

            this->errorTerms[i].k_i_q_i + (forceClamped - forceUnclamped),

values.title: Switch from rubble plugin to manual placement

content.raw: Falling rubble has performance impact, presumably because the pieces take a long time to come to rest. As a side benefit, the damping coefficients can be removed, which should lead to more realistic interactions between Atlas and the rublle.

values.title: Force Torque sensor does not give correct results for torque and is extremely noisy

content.html:
During testing of the wrist torque/force sensor we found that the resulting torques where not correct. We implemented a simple test consisting of three boxes connected by a revolute joint around the Y-axis, weight 100kg, 5kg and 1kg. We control all joints to zero angles using a simple PD controller. See image [torqueSensorTestWorld.png] and the world file [testWorld.world].

We set the <provide_feedback> to true in both joints (joint1 and joint2) and measured the wrench on the second box with 

physics::JointPtr sensor = model->GetJoint("joint1");

gazebo::physics::JointWrench wrench = sensor->GetForceTorque((unsigned int) 0);
robotStateForce->set_fx(wrench.body2Force.x);
robotStateForce->set_fy(wrench.body2Force.y);
robotStateForce->set_fz(wrench.body2Force.z);

robotStateForce->set_tx(wrench.body2Torque.x);
robotStateForce->set_ty(wrench.body2Torque.y);
robotStateForce->set_tz(wrench.body2Torque.z);

At t = 17s we dropped a drill on top of the top box. Because the torque sensors are really noisy, even at iter=1500 and dt=0.0001, we added a 1Hz lowpass filter to the data.

We plotted the torque part of the wrench in [Joint1WrenchTorque.png]. For comparison, we added the joint torque. The wrench is measured in the Center of Mass frame of box2 (middle box), so we expect the wrench around the Y axis to be at least 10 Nm due box3 (1kg * 9.81 m/s^2 * 1m), however it is zero all the time. For comparison, we also plotted the torque around joint 1. The torque around the X and Z axis is expected to be around zero, but change erratically when we dropped the drill on box3.

The force part of the wrench is plotted in [Joint1WrenchForce.png], and this seems to be correct (force in the z direction is about 60N).

Even if the torque data where correct, it is extremely noisy especially when the links are in contact.

values.title: Joint damping coefficients are enormous

content.raw:
In the 2.3.1 update, the viscous damping coefficients for following joints were increased from 0.1 to 10:

* back_lbz
* back_mby
* back_ubx
* l_leg_uhz
* l_leg_mhx
* l_leg_lhy
* r_leg_uhz
* r_leg_mhx
* r_leg_lhy

These damping coefficients are unrealistic and break our current controller. The original 0.1 values are much closer to what you would get on a real robot, and much more workable.

Could I ask what the reason was for increasing these damping coefficients in the first place? If it was to increase simulation stability, these two issues could be related:
https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/634/joint-velocity-limit-causes-significant
#!/osrf/sandia-hand/issue/3/damping-extremely-large

This last issue relates increasing damping to not hitting joint velocity limits, which we think are the source of the simulation instability.
content.html:
In the 2.3.1 update, the viscous damping coefficients for following joints were increased from 0.1 to 10:

  • back_lbz
  • back_mby
  • back_ubx
  • l_leg_uhz
  • l_leg_mhx
  • l_leg_lhy
  • r_leg_uhz
  • r_leg_mhx
  • r_leg_lhy

These damping coefficients are unrealistic and break our current controller. The original 0.1 values are much closer to what you would get on a real robot, and much more workable.

Could I ask what the reason was for increasing these damping coefficients in the first place? If it was to increase simulation stability, these two issues could be related: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/634/joint-velocity-limit-causes-significant #!/osrf/sandia-hand/issue/3/damping-extremely-large

This last issue relates increasing damping to not hitting joint velocity limits, which we think are the source of the simulation instability.

values.title: Force Torque sensors are extremely noisy at iter=50, sor=1.4

content.raw:
During testing of the force torque sensors I saw that they where extremely noisy. Using the tests written for [#193](#!/osrf/drcsim/issue/193/force-torque-sensor-does-not-give-correct) I measured the noise for iter=50, iter=200 and iter=250.

iter=50 (see iter50ForceTorque.png)
```
Signal noise
Mean
 Force X: 2.9184
 Force Y: 1.4692
 Force Z: -58.7554
 Torque X: -1.3587
 Torque Y: 42.4429
 Torque Z: 0.98366
Std dev
 Force X: 53.455
 Force Y: 58.4858
 Force Z: 33.9999
 Torque X: 55.7359
 Torque Y: 0.80908
 Torque Z: 42.8304
```

iter=200 (see iter200ForceTorque.png)
```
Signal noise
Mean
 Force X: 4.3924
 Force Y: 1.5287
 Force Z: -58.9146
 Torque X: -1.2543
 Torque Y: 42.4333
 Torque Z: 1.0472
Std dev
 Force X: 43.5975
 Force Y: 61.2231
 Force Z: 29.3226
 Torque X: 57.9369
 Torque Y: 0.61266
 Torque Z: 45.187
```

iter=250 (see iter250ForceTorque.png)
```
Signal noise
Mean
 Force X: 5.0497
 Force Y: -0.074208
 Force Z: -58.6046
 Torque X: 0.071245
 Torque Y: 42.4289
 Torque Z: -0.057907
Std dev
 Force X: 5.6372
 Force Y: 6.4062
 Force Z: 3.4137
 Torque X: 6.0927
 Torque Y: 0.075793
 Torque Z: 4.6055
```

It seems that the noise on the force torque sensor is drastically reduced when the number of iterations is increased from 200 to 250, however increasing from 50 to 200 doesn't seem to affect the noise at all.

Initial tests showed that increasing the global CFM decreases the noise as well, but greatly increases the joint constraint error. Maybe it is possible to increase the CFM locally.

values.title: Boxes are too far apart in qual_task_1.world

content.raw: The gaps in the stepping boxes in `qual_task_1.world` are too far apart.  We believe that they're farther apart than the robot can statically step, and they're certainly too far apart for the current behavior library to handle.  Bring them much closer together, with the goal of being able to cross them using just the behavior library as is.
content.html: The gaps in the stepping boxes in qual_task_1.world are too far apart. We believe that they're farther apart than the robot can statically step, and they're certainly too far apart for the current behavior library to handle. Bring them much closer together, with the goal of being able to cross them using just the behavior library as is.
